description:
Xenopus laevis, also known as the African clawed frog, is a species of aquatic frog native to parts of Africa. It is a member of the genus Xenopus, which belongs to the family Pipidae.

Xenopus laevis is a relatively large frog, with an average body length of 5-12 cm. It has a flattened, streamlined body and large, webbed hind feet that aid in swimming. The skin is smooth and generally olive-green or brown in color, with a pale belly. The frog's eyes are small and positioned on the top of the head, allowing it to see above the water's surface while the rest of the body remains submerged.

This species is well-known for its ability to live entirely in the water, with no larval tadpole stage. The young develop directly from eggs into small, fully-formed frogs. Xenopus laevis is an opportunistic carnivore, feeding on a variety of aquatic invertebrates, small vertebrates, and even other smaller frogs.

Xenopus laevis has played a significant role in scientific research, particularly in the fields of developmental biology and endocrinology, due to its unique reproductive characteristics and the ease with which it can be maintained in laboratory settings.
